posts.title: 10 Holiday Movies and What to Read After
posts.text: Before you get inspired to leave your big city job to settle down with your ruggedly handsome childhood crush who owns a struggling toy store, cozy up with a new holiday novel guaranteed to give you the same cozy, familiar feelings as your favorite holiday movie.

posts.title: Views from the Digital Collections: Holidays in NYC
posts.text: NYPL Digital Collections contain thousands of photos of New York City, including street scenes of the Holidays in the Big Apple.

posts.title: Nella Larsen and Passing in NYPL's Collections
posts.text: The Schomburg Center holds archival materials of Nella Larsen and The New York Public Library provides access to media that allows readers to explore Larsen’s work and legacy.

posts.title: Views from the Digital Collections: Times Square
posts.text: Located at the junction of Broadway and Seventh Avenue at 42nd Street, Times Square is one of the most recognizable intersections in the world and, for many, a quintessential tourist destination.

posts.title: Frightful Sights: Theatre in the Digital Collections
posts.text: From monsters to murderers, dozens of dark and thrilling plays have made it to the Great White Way. Explore these photos from some of the spookiest shows to ever hit Broadway.

posts.title: Views from the Digital Collections: Prospect Park
posts.text: Peruse these photos (and more in our Digital Archives) to see how this park in the heart of Brooklyn has changed (and stayed the same) over more than 150 years.

posts.title: Exploring Macbeth Productions in NYPL's Digital Collections
posts.text: Over the last several centuries, there have been hundreds of productions of 'Macbeth'. Our Digital Collections contain photos of many 'Macbeth' productions including the New York Shakespeare Festival’s 1989 production starring legendary Puerto Rican Actor Raul Julia, and a 1966 production starring one of the greatest American actors, James Earl Jones.

posts.title: Books Don't Cost A Thing: A #GoodbyeFines Playlist
posts.text: To celebrate a new chapter at the Library, we’ve put together a playlist of fun, revelatory songs to jam to on this fine day.

posts.title: Big-Hearted Novels for Fans of Starstruck
posts.text: If you love 'Starstruck' and other stories of odd couples and star-crossed lovers, check out these joyful stories of people who just can’t be together...until they can.

posts.title: Who Said It: Pooh or Proust?
posts.text: Winnie-the-Pooh's wisdom is so prolific that we bet you can’t distinguish his words from those of another literary heavyweight: Marcel Proust

posts.title: Your One and Only Source for Recommendations
posts.text: After nearly a decade off the air, 'Gossip Girl' is back and she’s off Blogspot and on Instagram. Before we dive into a new era, we’re taking a look back at the show that inspired it all and making reading recommendations for our favorite Upper East Siders.

posts.title: Nine New Nonfiction Books to Open Your World
posts.text: From stories of love within the American Prison System to the history of Los Angeles, and the science of sweat, these new nonfiction books span a wide range of topics guaranteed to open your world, or at least map your brain.

posts.title: Views from the Digital Collections: Coney Island
posts.text: Coney Island is one of the most famous destinations in New York City for both tourists and locals alike. Explore hundreds of photos of this hot spot in our Digital Collections.

posts.title: Happy Birthday Octavia Butler
posts.text: On her birthday, NYPL celebrates her life and legacy by sharing blog posts, reflections, videos, and more that honor Butler's significant contributions to the literary landscape.

posts.title: Views from the Digital Collections: Madison Square Garden
posts.text: The arena has been the site of historic sports matchups and legendary performances by some of the greatest artists of the last century. But the Madison Square Garden we know today, is not the same venue that opened to the world in 1874.

posts.title: Nine New Poetry Collections to Savor
posts.text: This summer, turn beach reading on its head and dive into one of these new poetry collections from longtime masters of the art and daring new voices.

posts.title: Views from the Digital Collections: The Brooklyn Bridge
posts.text: When this iconic bridge opened in 1883 it was the longest suspension bridge in the world. Explore photos of the Brooklyn Bridge over the years, from #NYPLDigitalCollections, and learn more about the history of this New York City landmark.

posts.title: The Post-COVID Community Mental Health Project
posts.text: Columbia University and NYPL are joining forces to assist New York City neighborhoods dealing with the mental health fallout of the COVID-19 pandemic.

posts.title: The Nanny's 'Fran Fine' as Books
posts.text: With the beloved '90s sitcom The Nanny now available on streaming services, many are returning to the show for its joyful love story, classic hijinks, and iconic costuming. To honor New York's own flashy girl from Flushing, we've paired some of Fran best looks with books!

posts.title: Views from the Digital Collections: The Empire State Building
posts.text: Over its nearly 100-year-history, the iconic building has caught the eye of generations of photographers.

posts.title: "One of the Family": Novels About Nannies
posts.text: From murderous nannies and struggling students to recent immigrants and emotionally fragile au pairs, these books transport readers into the lives of complicated families and the workers who help keep them together.

posts.title: Postcards for National Poetry Month
posts.text: We're celebrating with poems that capture the spirit of the city we’ve called home for 125 years. Send a poetry postcard to someone in your life!

posts.title: Books About the Internet As We Know It
posts.text: These novels explore our relationship to the world wide web and how it is constantly evolving.

posts.title: Celebrate Zines With Our Feminist Zine Name Generator!
posts.text: The riot grrl movement of the 1990s inspired a wave of feminist zines that gave creative, politically-minded young women the chance to create something that was wholly their own and share it with anyone willing to read. The names were always strong and catchy like, Bamboo Girl, Geekgirl, Hip Mama, GirlFrenzy, and more.

posts.title: Celebrity Memoirs Narrated by the Author
posts.text: Let your next listen be a story of passion, talent, and great luck.

posts.title: Enter the Jasmine Guillory Universe
posts.text: Her contemporary romance novels depict relatable characters navigating race, gender, friendships, careers, politics, and more. Oh, and they eat.

posts.title: Quiz Yourself on These Romantic Literary Quotes
posts.text: Whether you love the classics or wait with baited breath for the latest release, we want to see if you can match these famous quotes with the popular novel.

posts.title: #RoarforNYC Through NYPL Digital Collections
posts.text: Our collections are home to images of New York City throughout the years and we’re sharing some of our favorites including #TBT photos of branches, famous quotes about New York City, and information about books on our 125 NYC Books We Love Book List.

posts.title: Christmas Movie & Book Pairings
posts.text: These books will give you the same warm, familiar feelings as your favorite holiday movie.

posts.title: Enter Our Time Machine: Halloween in South Brooklyn,1970s
posts.text: For six years in the seventies, Larry Racioppo photographed kids in costume in his Brooklyn neighborhood. The black-and-white images of superheroes, tiny tin men, skeletons, and witches remind viewers of the simple joy of being a child on Halloween.

posts.title: Discover the 2020 National Book Award Finalists
posts.text: Looking for your next book? This selection comes recommended from a panel of literary experts.

posts.title: Discover the Work of Poet Louise Glück
posts.text: The New York Public Library is proud to have many of her books available in our collections.
